dublinCore.dc:title: 119 HR 1931 IH: Access to Pediatric Technologies Act of 2025
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mr. Joyce of Pennsylvania (for himself and Mrs. Trahan) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce, and in addition to the Committee on Ways and Means, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To amend title XVIII of the Social Security Act to facilitate patient access to certain pediatric technologies.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Access to Pediatric Technologies Act of 2025.

subsection.text: Section 1848 of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1395w–4) is amended by adding at the end the following new subsection:

paragraph.text: For each qualifying pediatric technology (as defined in paragraph (4)) furnished on or after January 1, 2026, the Secretary shall, upon receipt of a manufacturer request under paragraph (3), establish national relative value units under the physician fee schedule established under this section, to the extent no such national relative value units have been established for such qualifying pediatric technology under such fee schedule.
The Secretary shall establish national relative value units for a qualifying pediatric technology under this subsection—

subparagraph.text: in accordance with the payment methodology established under this section and applicable regulations; and

using available data related to the qualifying pediatric technology, which may include applicable contractor pricing information, claims data, time and motion studies, invoice information, or other information used by the Secretary in establishing payment rates.

Upon written request to the Secretary from the manufacturer of a qualifying pediatric technology, the Secretary shall establish national relative value units under paragraph (1) through the annual rulemaking process for the physician fee schedule established under this section, in accordance with the timeline described in subparagraph (B).

clause.text: In the case where the Secretary receives a request under this paragraph on or before May 1 of a given year from a manufacturer with respect to a qualifying pediatric technology of the manufacturer, the Secretary shall establish national relative value units for the qualifying pediatric technology in the rulemaking process during that year for the physician fee schedule established under this section.

In the case where the Secretary receives a request under this paragraph after May 1 of a given year from a manufacturer with respect to a qualifying pediatric technology of the manufacturer, the Secretary shall establish national relative value units for the qualifying pediatric technology in the rulemaking process during the following year for the physician fee schedule established under this section.

subparagraph.text: A manufacturer submitting a request under paragraph with respect to a qualifying pediatric technology of the manufacturer shall include in such request information to verify that the technology is a qualifying pediatric technology and to allow the Secretary to establish national relative value units for such technology, including (to the extent available) contractor pricing information, claims data, time and motion studies, invoice information, or other relevant information.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, the term qualifying pediatric technology means a medical device that is—

subparagraph.text: approved, cleared, or authorized under section 510(k), 513(f)(2), or 515 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (21 U.S.C. 360(k), 360c(f)(2), 360e);
described by a temporary Level I HCPCS Code intended for emerging technologies, services, or procedures; and

clause.text: used as part of a procedure predominantly performed on pediatric patients; or
has otherwise been specifically designed for safe and effective use in pediatric populations.

paragraph.text: Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to require coverage of a qualifying pediatric technology under this title or alter the requirements of section 1862(a)(1)(A).
